results.title: The Navigator: A Medieval Odyssey
results.creator_credit: Arenafilm, New Zealand Film Commission, John Maynard, Gary Hannam and Vincent Ward
results.brief_description: The navigator is remarkable because of its absorbing story that links medieval fears and fortunes to our times, while confirming director Vincent Ward as an original talent. It is Cumbria 1348, the year of the Black Death. A young visionary tells his fellow miners that their community may survive the plague if they place a spire on a distant cathedral before dawn. So, from their grim, snowbound Lake District, they dig down an old mine-shaft to the other side of the world, emerging in an Eastman-coloured present day Auckland, New Zealand. Cast includes Bruce Lyons, Chris Haywood and Hamish McFarlane.

results.title: The Navigator
results.brief_description: Buster “Keaton moves in the mechanised world of today like the inhabitant of another planet. He gazes with frozen bewilderment at a nightmare reality. Inventions and contrivances like deck chairs and railroad engines seem insuperably animate to him, in the same measure that human beings become impersonal.” Arthur Mayer. In “The Navigator”, which grossed more than any other Keaton film, it was a huge luxury liner. There is the famous sequence in which Keaton gloomily sets about cooking his breakfast, in a ship’s galley equipped to feed five hundred people. Painfully, he times an egg as it boils in a huge cauldron. The plot of “The Navigator” inverts the problem of Robinson Crusoe. Crusoe had to create the rudiments of civilisation on a desert island. Keaton, playing a dim-witted millionaire, finds himself and his girl marooned in an over-technical environment. He has to create the basis for crude existence. Considered by many Keaton buffs to be the funniest film he ever made.

results.title: The Navajo: shepherds of the desert
results.creator_credit: Southventure Films, Coleman Film Enterprises and J. Donald McIntyre
results.brief_description: Describes a day in the life of a typical Navajo family. Shows the family at work, the tending and shearing sheep, rug weaving and the family’s social life.

results.title: The Naughty owlet
results.creator_credit: Hungarofilm, Gyula Macskassy and Gyorgy Varwai
results.brief_description: An animated story of a family of baby owls who live in a hollow tree. One little owl refuses to learn to fly and while his brothers work hard, he spends his time looking at television. One day he is caught outside the nest by a fox and needs desperately to fly to get away. The owl flounders and is almost caught, but with the help of his brothers gets away.

results.title: The Nature of tuberculosis
results.brief_description: Shows infected lung, tuberculosis operation in Japan, the infection and how it grows, removal of the infected part and possible treatment with rest and new drugs. Supervised by Dr Hideo Kumabe with technical guidance by the Research Institute for Tuberculosis of the Anti-tuberculosis Association Japan.

results.title: The Nature of science: how ideas change
results.creator_credit: Coronet Instructional Films and Dick Larson
results.brief_description: Scientific ideas are shown to be in a continual stage of modification and change. We investigate how and why scientific ideas change and in so doing clarify the criteria used to evaluate them, such as their accuracy, simplicity, productivity and scope. For primary grades.

results.title: The Nature of salt
results.brief_description: A short documentary showing how salt affects different environments, for example, how it kills grass. Also shows some laboratory-like experiments such as “water taking salt from soil”. Towards the end of the film we also see aspects of ‘salt mining’ via live footage and diagrams.

results.title: The Nature of prejudice: ' I wear my people's clothes'
results.creator_credit: Playing With Time, Canadian Council of Christians and Jews, Linda Schuyler and Kit Hood
results.brief_description: Attempts to break down people’s prejudices to people of other cultures by putting forward the view that prejudice is the result of fear based on lack of understanding. Interviews several people of ethnic origins living in Canada who still follow the customs and beliefs of their own cultures, including the wearing of particular clothing and hairstyles. Narrated by Professor Jamshed Mavalwala. Suitable for upper primary, lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: The Nature of paradise (A)
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Steve Thomas, Daryl Dellora, Sally Ingleton, John Moore and Lucinda Gamble
results.brief_description: Three women - Trish Molloy (artist), Monique La Fontaine (artist), Sharon Wiggan (law student) - tell their stories, each from a personal perspective, of their relationship and connection to the Western Australian north-west coastal town of Broome. Trish and Monique are travellers who have separately found their way to Broome and stayed and Sharon is an Aboriginal Australian who was brought up in Broome, left to study in Perth and who has now returned home to Broome. The documentary explores each woman’s emotional and spiritual attachment to the town, to their surrounding environment and their kinship with the people of Broome and with each other. Evocative and beautifully photographed by Veronica Iacono, and sensitively scripted and directed by Lucinda Gamble, “The Nature of paradise” is stunningly rich in images and colour, of reds and blues, of the earth, sky and the ocean and is accompanied by an ambient musical soundtrack, “Free diving” written and performed by Lorrei Coffin. Interspersed throughout the documentary are images of both Trish and Monique’s paintings which reflect their transitional journey to this place called “paradise”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Steve Thomas, Daryl Dellora, Sally Ingleton, John Moore and Lucinda Gamble

results.title: The Nature of paradise
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television and Lucinda Gamble
